name: L'attach?
keyboard: Full-stroke 84 keys with function keys and numeric keypad
ports: Serial port, Telephone and modem lines, Ext. FDD unit, 1 expansion card slot, Parallel, RGB and Composite video
description:
"L'attach?" was the first Bull attempt to produce a portable PC-compatible computer. It was not made in France by Bull, but in Japan.

This computer was mainly sold to french public services, as they were obliged at the time to buy french-made computers. But "L'attach?" was not very successful in the private sector when it was launched, because there were many competing that were technically more advanced and cheaper.

The system hardware was made of two separate modules. A motherboard/display module, and a backup module that could be fitted with one or two 3.5" 720 KB floppy disc drives or a 20 MB hard disk.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> SYSTEM MODULES</strong></font><br><blockquote>On left, the main motherboard/display module<br> On right, the backup module is fastened to the main module with four unsightly screws. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Trap door for Parallel, RGB and composite video connectors<br> <b>(2)</b> External power supply unit DIN plug<br> <b>(3)</b> External 5.25" floppy disc unit connector<br> <b>(4)</b> Trap door of the optional expansion board housing</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> 3.5" 720 KB floppy disc drive<br> <b>(2)</b> Expansion board housing<br> <b>(3)</b> RJ-45 connectors for telephone and modem lines. An optional modem card could be inserted into the main module<br> <b>(4)</b> Serial connector<br> <b>(5)</b> Contrast adjustment</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE BAG</strong></font><br><blockquote>A nice and high quality bag.<br><br> <b>(1)</b> When we found it, this bag kept a trace of the last time of its active life: an air trip from Marseille to Paris! </blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 6000 MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> WE HAVE A NEW APPROACH TO DISTRIBUTED PROCESSING THAT WORKS <br><br> Already implemented are electronic mail, word processing, complete cost accounting with inventory control and more. The secret is a new technology called Functionally Structured Distribution (FSD). At last, a system to organize and manage distributed processing applications that is really up and running. FSD technology is especially applicable to installa­tions that require:<br> • Unlimited expandability supporting extremely large data bases and terminals in many cities.<br> • User-friendly software easily programmed in high level languages (COBOL, FORTRAN, and BASIC)<br> • System reliability (due to distributed hardware) while maintaining multiple levels of data security.<br> • Compatibility with existing mainframes and networks (including the Bell System). <br><br> We are presently installing Billings 6000 Computer Systems which take full advantage of distributed processing utilizing FSD technology. The 6000 Computer supports multiple hard disk drives with capacities of up to 64 Mbytes (formatted), streaming tapes for backup, auto-dial modems (2400 baud synchronous) for communications, and flexible disk drives for smaller installations.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NOT REALLY AN IMSAI!</strong></font><br><blockquote>In october 1979, the IMSAI company went bankrupt. The IMSAI brand name and the spare parts stock were sold to the <b>Fischer-Freitas</b> Company. <br><br> This 1982 advert shows a Z80 CP/M based computer Fisher-Freitas tried to sell with the IMSAI name, without success.<br><br> Fisher-Freitas is still selling original parts for the 8080 model! and continue maintaining a nice 8080 history web site (see the Web links section).</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to chrism3667 for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy has so much power in his hands that he has attracted two girls (so far) in his swimming-pool ! <br><br> Notice the classical symbol of the 80s adverts : the glass of orange juice with a straw...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pong-story.com" target="_blank">www.pong-story.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>TO-7/70 playing AIRBUS, a flight sim...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote>TopView, one of the first serious multitasking tool for the IBM PC.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine, July 1985</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> F.D. UNIT ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>BBC floppy disc unit was delivered with a 8271 FD controller chip and a Filing System software in ROM to be fitted into the BBC system.<br> Two versions of F.D. units were available:<br>   - A single drive unit, single side, single density, 100 KB space.<br>   - A dual drive version, double side, double density, 800 KB space. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b> </p></blockquote>

media: 1 x 3.5'' FDD. Optional 20 MB hard disk and second FDD
